comment.author: 79925372@N00
comment._content: The bridge is called the Korenbrug and still stands today (recently restored). The tower is that if Leiden City Hall.

comment.author: 9539502@N02
comment._content: Looking on to the Korenbrug at night.

comment.author: 56812698@N00
comment._content: 'koren' in dutch is 'wheat' in english 'corn' would have been 'mais' in dutch. this is a common mistake but please relabel your text

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
The confusion goes back to the so-called Corn Laws in England in 1832, which actually regulated what Americans called "wheat." At that time, American corn (as in corn on cobs), or maize, was virtually unknown in England.

Incidentally, "cob," as in cobweb, was another name for a spider -- but that's a whole different can of worms . . . .

comment.author: 10258495@N02
comment._content:
According to the OED, corn has meant seed or grain in English as far back as the 9th century, but it tends to refer to different grains in different regions.

"As a general term the word includes all the cereals, wheat, rye, barley, oats, maize, rice, etc., and, with qualification (as black corn, pulse corn), is extended to leguminous plants, as pease, beans, etc., cultivated for food. Locally, the word, when not otherwise qualified, is often understood to denote that kind of cereal which is the leading crop of the district; hence in the greater part of England ‘corn’ is = wheat, in North Britain and Ireland = oats; in the U.S. the word, as short for Indian corn, is restricted to maize."

comment.author: 52816187@N03
comment._content: simply amazing and lovely photo. i went to school in Leiden and recognized the bridge immediately before scrolling down to the caption. the tower on the town hall looks markedly different today, but otherwise this could be a street scene from last week. even the shops on the street look nearly substantially the same, same feel.  lovely photo. thank you.

comment.author: 14817406@N04
comment._content:
I don't think the Town Hall tower is very different - see photo taken today! The Town Hall itself is different - it  burnt down in 1929 and only the facade (not visible here) and the tower remain from the previous building - they may have had to reconstruct the tower a bit, but it's basically the same.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/debbcollins/5546590081/]
